mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis + protects from beta-lactamase
major_contraindications: Penicillin allergy,History of jaundice/hepatic dysfunction with amoxicillin-clavulanate
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Allopurinol (increased rash risk),Oral contraceptives (reduced effectiveness)
food_interactions: Take with food to reduce GI upset
notes: Broader spectrum than amoxicillin alone. First-line for many infections in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
major_drug_interactions: Allopurinol (increased rash),Oral contraceptives (reduced effectiveness),Warfarin (increased bleeding risk)
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after meals)
notes: Injectable form common in Nigerian hospitals. Less bioavailable than amoxicillin orally.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
notes: IV/IM only. Drug of choice for streptococcal infections. Essential in Nigerian hospitals.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits cell wall synthesis (resistant to staphylococcal beta-lactamase)
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after food)
notes: First-line for staphylococcal skin infections. Common in Nigeria for boils/abscesses.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach for best absorption
notes: Oral penicillin for streptococcal infections. Cheaper than amoxicillin.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
notes: Long half-life allows once-daily dosing. Widely used in Nigerian hospitals for severe infections.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
notes: Oral 3rd generation cephalosporin. Good for UTIs and gonorrhea.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
food_interactions: Take oral form with food for better absorption
notes: Good for respiratory and skin infections. Available oral and IV.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
notes: Widely used for skin and soft tissue infections in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
food_interactions: Take with food for better absorption
notes: Good oral alternative to injectable cephalosporins.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis (anti-pseudomonal)
notes: Important for Pseudomonas infections in Nigerian hospitals.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
notes: Alternative to ceftriaxone with similar spectrum.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits cell wall + protects from beta-lactamase
notes: Reserved for multidrug-resistant infections. Expensive but effective.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
major_contraindications: Macrolide allergy,History of cholestatic jaundice with azithromycin
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Digoxin (increased digoxin levels),Statins (myopathy risk),QT-prolonging drugs
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach or with food
notes: Long half-life allows short courses (3-5 days). Popular in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
major_contraindications: Macrolide allergy,Concurrent use with ergot alkaloids or pimozide
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Theophylline (increased levels),Carbamazepine (increased levels),Statins (myopathy risk),QT-prolonging drugs
food_interactions: Take with food to reduce GI upset
notes: Penicillin alternative. GI side effects common. Cheap and available in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
major_contraindications: Macrolide allergy,Concurrent QT-prolonging drugs,History of QT prolongation
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Statins (myopathy risk),Theophylline (increased levels),Digoxin (increased levels),QT-prolonging drugs
notes: Better tolerated than erythromycin. Used in H. pylori eradication.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
notes: Less commonly used than azithromycin in Nigeria but available.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
black_box_warning_text: Risk of tendon rupture (especially Achilles), peripheral neuropathy, QT prolongation, CNS effects, aortic aneurysm risk. Avoid in children and elderly due to cartilage/tendon damage.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Theophylline (increased levels),NSAIDs (increased seizure risk),Dairy products/antacids (reduced absorption),Tizanidine (contraindicated)
food_interactions: Avoid dairy products, take 2 hours before or 6 hours after antacids
notes: Widely used in Nigeria but significant side effects. FDA black box warnings for tendon/nerve damage.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
black_box_warning_text: Risk of tendon rupture, peripheral neuropathy, QT prolongation, CNS effects, aortic aneurysm. FDA black box warnings.
notes: More expensive than ciprofloxacin but better respiratory coverage.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
black_box_warning_text: Similar black box warnings as other fluoroquinolones. Higher risk of QT prolongation than ciprofloxacin. Hepatotoxicity risk.
notes: Reserved for serious infections. Expensive. Used in MDR-TB regimens in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
notes: Also available as eye/ear drops. Less commonly used systemically in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (30S ribosomal subunit)
major_contraindications: Pregnancy (tooth discoloration in fetus),Children under 8 years (permanent tooth staining),Esophageal disorders
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Oral contraceptives (reduced effectiveness),Antacids/dairy (reduced absorption),Retinoids (increased intracranial pressure)
food_interactions: Avoid dairy products, take with full glass of water, stay upright 30 min after
notes: Widely used in Nigeria for malaria prophylaxis and acne. Once or twice daily dosing.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (30S ribosomal subunit)
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Oral contraceptives (reduced effectiveness),Antacids/dairy (reduced absorption),Iron supplements (reduced absorption)
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach, avoid dairy 2 hours before/after
notes: Cheaper than doxycycline but less bioavailable. Four times daily dosing.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (30S ribosomal subunit)
black_box_warning_text: Increased mortality risk compared to other antibiotics in clinical trials. Reserved for serious infections when alternatives unavailable.
notes: Reserved for MDR infections. IV only. Black box warning. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (30S ribosomal subunit)
major_drug_interactions: Loop diuretics (increased ototoxicity),Vancomycin (increased nephrotoxicity),Amphotericin B (increased nephrotoxicity),Neuromuscular blockers (enhanced paralysis)
notes: Narrow therapeutic window. Requires monitoring. Common in Nigerian hospitals for serious infections.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (30S ribosomal subunit)
notes: Reserved for aminoglycoside-resistant infections. More expensive than gentamicin.

mechanism_of_action: Disrupts DNA in anaerobic organisms and protozoa
major_contraindications: Alcohol use (disulfiram reaction),First trimester pregnancy (avoid if possible),Hypersensitivity to nitroimidazoles
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Lithium (increased lithium levels),Disulfiram (psychotic reactions),Alcohol (severe disulfiram-like reaction)
food_interactions: Avoid alcohol during treatment and 48 hours after (severe reaction)
notes: Essential for anaerobic and protozoal infections. Avoid alcohol completely. Common in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
major_contraindications: History of C. difficile colitis,Hypersensitivity to lincosamides
black_box_warning_text: Risk of C. difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and pseudomembranous colitis. Discontinue if severe diarrhea develops.
food_interactions: Take with full glass of water, can take with or without food
notes: Excellent for anaerobic infections and dental abscesses. Risk of C. diff colitis.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits folic acid synthesis at two steps
major_contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy,Severe renal impairment,Megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency,Pregnancy (especially first trimester)
food_interactions: Take with full glass of water, maintain adequate hydration
notes: Cheap and widely available in Nigeria. First-line for many UTIs and PCP prophylaxis in HIV.

mechanism_of_action: Damages bacterial DNA
major_contraindications: Renal impairment (CrCl <30 ml/min),Pregnancy at term (risk of hemolytic anemia in newborn),G6PD deficiency
major_drug_interactions: Antacids (reduced absorption),Probenecid (increased nitrofurantoin levels and toxicity)
food_interactions: Take with food or milk to enhance absorption and reduce GI upset
notes: Only effective for urinary tract infections (not systemic). Good for uncomplicated UTIs.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
major_drug_interactions: Aminoglycosides (increased nephrotoxicity/ototoxicity),Loop diuretics (increased ototoxicity),Nephrotoxic drugs (increased nephrotoxicity)
food_interactions: Not applicable (IV only, oral for C. diff)
notes: Reserved for serious gram-positive infections including MRSA. Requires monitoring. Essential in Nigerian hospitals.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
monitoring_type: Complete blood count (myelosuppression), Peripheral neuropathy signs
major_drug_interactions: MAOIs (hypertensive crisis),Serotonergic drugs (serotonin syndrome),Tyramine-rich foods (hypertensive crisis)
food_interactions: Avoid tyramine-rich foods (aged cheese, cured meats, fermented foods)
notes: Oral option for MRSA. Expensive but useful when IV access difficult. Myelosuppression risk with prolonged use.

mechanism_of_action: Disrupts bacterial cell membrane
notes: Last-resort antibiotic for multidrug-resistant gram-negatives. Nephrotoxic. Essential for MDR in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits cell wall + protects from beta-lactamase
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Probenecid (increased levels),Aminoglycosides (inactivation if mixed together)
notes: Broad-spectrum for serious hospital infections. Covers Pseudomonas. Common in Nigerian hospitals.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis (broad spectrum)
major_drug_interactions: Valproic acid (significantly reduced valproate levels - seizure risk),Probenecid (increased meropenem levels)
notes: Broad-spectrum carbapenem for serious infections. Reserved for ESBL and other resistant organisms in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits cell wall + protects from renal metabolism
major_drug_interactions: Valproic acid (reduced levels - seizure risk),Ganciclovir (increased seizure risk),Probenecid (increased imipenem levels)
notes: Cilastatin prevents renal metabolism of imipenem. Higher seizure risk than meropenem.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis
major_drug_interactions: Valproic acid (reduced levels - seizure risk),Probenecid (increased ertapenem levels)
notes: Long half-life allows once-daily dosing. No Pseudomonas coverage. Good for ESBL E. coli in Nigeria.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (50S ribosomal subunit)
monitoring_type: Complete blood count (aplastic anemia risk), Gray baby syndrome in neonates
black_box_warning_text: Risk of aplastic anemia (rare but fatal), Gray baby syndrome in neonates, bone marrow suppression. Use only when safer alternatives unavailable.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased INR),Phenytoin (increased levels),Oral hypoglycemics (hypoglycemia),Rifampicin (reduced chloramphenicol levels)
food_interactions: Take on empty stomach (1 hour before or 2 hours after meals)
notes: Historical first-line for typhoid in Nigeria. Now reserved due to aplastic anemia risk. Still used for bacterial meningitis in some areas.
